body:
This is a lovely idea and something I've been thinking about for a log while. I would also want to provide pretraines encoders, decoders and combiners.
This has not ahppened so far mostly because of the time it requires, but it is definitely something I want to do.
If someone from the community is interested in helping on this, I would be glad to direct and support them!

Hey, sounds good.
We don't have time to help you with programming but we would upload pretrained models as much as we can.
At the moment we are especially building CV models.
I'd love to support this sinces Ludwig is a great opportunity to give prototyping tasks to my colleagues who don't have any idea about DL ;)
A pretty lazy solution would be an GitHub repo with json file containing links to this models.

I would proably study how Hugging Face does it, as their solution works very well, and try to replicate it (or improve over it) to get this right once and for all, avoiding the super lazy solution, but I'm open to suggestions ;)

@w4nderlust 
my first suggestion for a model hub 

example usage: 
base url with github pages: "https://flozi00.github.io/modelhub/" + folder (models / encoders / decoders / combiners) + username + modelname
https://flozi00.github.io/modelhub/models/flozi00/titanic_model.json

https://github.com/flozi00/modelhub

Thank you, this is a very nice starting point :)

n alternative for the entries:
```
{
	"type": "model",  // model, encoer, combiner, decoder
	"path": "http://models.a-ware.io/titanic.zip",
        "version": "1",
	"ludwig_version": "0.3-alpha",
	"dataset_name": "titanic",
	"dataset_path": None,  //optional, for public datasets
	"tags": {...},  //useful for search in the future
	"description": "This model was trained from the ludwig tutorials",
}
```

I am thinking about replacing the description with an markdown file as huggingface does for the description, comments, code snippets and model definition file in yaml format.

The type is already defined with the folders, is it necessary to do it twice ?
Today I would start with generating an merged list of all files, is it okay when the type get filled there automatically ?
When the list is ready I would start with an simple UI to display the models and making an search mask

> I am thinking about replacing the description with an markdown file as huggingface does for the description, comments, code snippets and model definition file in yaml format.

Sounds good, curious to see how it looks like after the change ;)
 
> The type is already defined with the folders, is it necessary to do it twice ?

I wold say yes, i can see how it can seem redundant, but if in the future we want to place a little elasticsearch instance in front of it to do search, having the field may be useful.

> Today I would start with generating an merged list of all files, is it okay when the type get filled there automatically ?
> When the list is ready I would start with an simple UI to display the models and making an search mask

That sounds great, thank you!

An basic implementation of the Web UI is available here: https://models.a-ware.io/
But there is still a lot to do, especially with searching, filtering or even the UI itself.

So far you can search for model names like in HF and if you click on them the MD details as well as the json definition will be shown.

I am not a Php or JS developer, but maybe my colleague can have a look at it.
The json files will be edited later as you want to have it, the UI for creating this json files will be pushed later too.
Thank you @flozi00 this looks very handy :)

Are you familiar with GitHub actions ?
I'd like to add automated test for pull request which downloads the zipped model, extract it and check if it's loading successfully.

I will give the modelhub an similar style as Ludwig docs have, clean up code etc.
When that's ready I could start adding an user management to make the upload API directly to the modelhub or do you think GitHub is the better way to do so ?

> Are you familiar with GitHub actions ?
> I'd like to add automated test for pull request which downloads the zipped model, extract it and check if it's loading successfully.

I'm not super familiar, but I believe that is a good way to do it. I believe @tgaddair is more familiar with them and give you suggestions.

> I will give the modelhub an similar style as Ludwig docs have, clean up code etc.
> When that's ready I could start adding an user management to make the upload API directly to the modelhub or do you think GitHub is the better way to do so ?

Not sure how feasible it is, but a very great way could be that every submitted model becomes a PR that then I decide to merge or not or I can ask to revise/improve before merging. This way we can take advantage of the GitHub user management. How does this sound?

> Not sure how feasible it is, but a very great way could be that every submitted model becomes a PR that then I decide to merge or not or I can ask to revise/improve before merging. This way we can take advantage of the GitHub user management. How does this sound?

I don't know if it is possible using php.
The user would need to login using his Github data and can't use the social auth login button.
I think no one would insert his login data for Github.

If you want to make sure that the model is accessible we need to make an automated test to check the paths or uploading the model while merging the PR to an own server.

> I don't know if it is possible using php.
> The user would need to login using his Github data and can't use the social auth login button.
> I think no one would insert his login data for Github.

This looks like it though https://www.codexworld.com/login-with-github-oauth-api-using-php/

> If you want to make sure that the model is accessible we need to make an automated test to check the paths or uploading the model while merging the PR to an own server.

That sounds very reasonable.

I tried this out and it seems like you can't create an PR using the GitHub Apis this way.
I found examples where users cloned repos or committed to existing but I found no way to create an PR programmatically without automating the browser using selenium or something similar.

What's the biggest size of an zipped model ?
GitHub allows uploading files smaller than 100mb, with Ludwig 0.2 I didn't find an model bigger than this.
I will try the hf_transformers branche later and check the size.

In this case we could use an GitHub repo + GitHub pages as download server, hopefully it is not forbidden for such an use case ^^

Edit:
Otherwise I would take the username from GitHub oauth, create an seperated folder named by the username and store the uploaded model there.
Then the model is online and only the model card is missing.

> I tried this out and it seems like you can't create an PR using the GitHub Apis this way.
> I found examples where users cloned repos or committed to existing but I found no way to create an PR programmatically without automating the browser using selenium or something similar.

Got it. It's a shame, but it's fine to do without ;)

> What's the biggest size of an zipped model ?
> GitHub allows uploading files smaller than 100mb, with Ludwig 0.2 I didn't find an model bigger than this.
> I will try the hf_transformers branche later and check the size.
> 
> In this case we could use an GitHub repo + GitHub pages as download server, hopefully it is not forbidden for such an use case ^^

I don't think it's forbidden, but 100mb is a pretty small size. It may be fine for now, but probably in the future we want users to either post the models and we manage saving them somewhere and keeping hte links, or they can provide a link to download the zip and we have some code that downloads it. I would prefer the first option, but it looks like it requires infrastructure.

> Edit:
> Otherwise I would take the username from GitHub oauth, create an seperated folder named by the username and store the uploaded model there.
> Then the model is online and only the model card is missing.

That may be fine, but the 100mb limit would still be there.

> That may be fine, but the 100mb limit would still be there.

There is no limit in this case.
We take the username by GitHub oauth, create an folder named by this, outside of the repo.
The models get stored on the hosting server then.
It's pretty similar to HF modelhub, anyone can upload models but the model cards needs to be reviewed from the team.

Which way to use ?
Hosted by GitHub pages or custom infrastructure ?

The following might be a suggestion:
https://github.com/flozi00/modelhub/tree/master/models/flozi00

In this version the paths are relative and you can host it on any server, you just have to enter the base url in the client.
Only the UI needs PHP support.

The models can be checked before they are merged, the functionality can be done somehow via the github actions.

Via git lfs (https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-large-files/configuring-git-large-file-storage) it should be possible to manage files larger than 100 MB, I would have to deal with that.
This looks convincing :) If lfs allow for bigger files, that sounds pretty nice to me.
Okay, then I will check the automated test using Github actions, trying to make the css looking better and then we could start integrating it into ludwig.

```
import dload
from pathlib import Path


def download_model(model_type, model_name, base_url = "https://models.a-ware.io/", base_path= "/tmp/ludwig/"):
    Path(base_path).mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    Path(base_path + model_type + "/").mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    dload.save_unzip(base_url + model_type + "/" + model_name + ".zip" , base_path + model_type + "/" + model_name )


```

This library handles all the necceassary steps, the above function can successfully download and unzip the model from model hub.
The modelhub has material design now, I will check to re-design the details view or resize the view.

Looks pretty cool! Only thing I suggest: when creating paths, use `os.path.join()` as it will respect the current os path separator (the current code won't work on windows, but with my suggestion it will for instance).

So, only the ludwig implementation is missing now.
The models can be stored everywhere (I will upload them to our S3 storage), the URL needs to be given in models json.
Every commit to the repo gets synced to the webserver instantly.
I will try to make the CSS looks better, could you insert the download function to ludwigs code ? I don't know where to do so exactly.
Actually I am training an address validation model for my work, after this I will train on kaggle datasets again.
